Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of a Decision Aid and Motivational Interviewing for Knee Osteoarthritis

Background: Total knee arthroplasty (TKA) is effective for moderate to severe knee osteoarthritis (OA), yet black patients are less willing to undergo TKA than white patients. This study evaluated whether a decision aid and motivational interviewing improve referrals to orthopaedic surgery and willingness to undergo TKA.

Methods: In a two-group randomised controlled trial, 493 black adults aged ≥50 with moderate to severe knee OA were enrolled from urban primary care clinics. Participants were randomised to receive either a decision-aid video and motivational interviewing or an educational booklet on OA. The primary outcome was referral to orthopaedic surgery at 12 months. Secondary outcome was willingness to undergo TKA. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed. Blinding was not specified.

Results: Of 493 randomised, 253 were in the control group and 240 in the treatment group. Analysis was intention-to-treat. Referral rates were 36% in the control group and 32% in the treatment group (OR, 0.81; 95% CI, 0.56–1.18; p = 0.277). Willingness to undergo TKA did not differ at 2 weeks or 12 months. No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: The intervention did not improve referrals or willingness for TKA compared to the control. Further research is needed to develop effective tools for improving surgical treatment decisions in OA.

Trial registration: Not provided.

Funding: Not specified.
